stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a Bowser-themed industrial level, focusing on an intensive, iterative design process for the background ocean to create an illusion of vastness on N64 hardware. He also fixed visual bugs, integrated a new asset from Biobak, and analyzed the level's performance.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered a massive, accidental performance gain after realizing he was using an unoptimized model export format; correcting it nearly doubled the performance on N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: I found out when we were in 64 testing this level and it already hit 30 FPS. I Was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DX2. So we had twice the verdict loads twice the triangle comments... and it still ran fine.

development_findings.summary: A significant, project-wide bug that caused crashes on real N64 hardware has been identified and fixed, leading to a major improvement in the game's stability.
development_findings.quote: I think I found the bug that caused only Up64 to crash. And now RTYI is so stable on the N64.

development_findings.summary: After extensive experimentation, Kaze concluded that the standard skybox technique (NFBG) was not viable for this level, leading him to develop a custom solution for the background.
development_findings.quote: An NFBG doesn't work if the elements in your level are touching the background.

development_findings.summary: The decision to use a P-switch as an interaction mechanic was a deliberate nod to the design patterns of Bowser levels in the original Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: I like the switch, you know why I do? It's because every Bowser level in Mario 64 uses this exact switch to help Mario beat the stage. This is just a very Mario 64 Bowser design.

development_findings.summary: Kaze troubleshooted a critical bug causing level geometry to disappear, eventually tracing the memory corruption issue to a specific coin formation object he had placed.
development_findings.quote: There's some memory corruption somewhere... I think the yellow coin model got unloaded.

development_findings.summary: Kaze highlighted a major update to the NEMU64 emulator, which has become a powerful new tool for the team to debug the game, including its GDB debugger support.
development_findings.quote: A new emulator dropped recently called NEMU64... And you can debug everything with it. You can debug this playlist with it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze was approached by a merchandise company to produce physical N64-style boxes for his games, which he is considering as a potential legal revenue stream.
context_findings.quote: Dude, when I sell RTYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal. And then I would also make a ROM that's just the OST and sell that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy is that he is most passionate about whatever part of the project he is currently creating.
context_findings.quote: My favorite one is always the most recent level I made.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong technical opinion that C is superior to C++, viewing object-oriented classes as an "unnecessary obstruction".
context_findings.quote: I think C++ is just a shitty version of C. Here's my hot take for the day. Actually, never mind. There's one good thing in C++ and that is templates.

context_findings.summary: Kaze balances the development of the project with a full-time job as a programmer, which dictates his available work hours.
context_findings.quote: I have a full-time job on the side. So that's why I don't have too much time to just work on this all the time.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains that many compiler warnings come from the original, unoptimized Mario 64 code, while others are the intended result of his own performance optimizations that the compiler flags.
context_findings.quote: It's warning me that I'm writing good code. What do you want me to do? Write bad code?

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned being approached for input on a significant drama within the beta Mario 64 romhacking community concerning the B3313 project.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a new, custom 3D model for the P-switch, which Kaze immediately praised for its quality and efficiency before implementing it into the level.
biobak.quote: This is so much better than the one we had before. This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.

biobak.summary: Biobak actively contributed design ideas for the level's background during the stream, suggesting a color gradient that Kaze used as the basis for the final look.
biobak.quote: I think Biobak wanted us to do a blue gradient here so let's just add it before he tells me to do it.

badub.summary: Kaze played a song from the game's original soundtrack during the stream and praised it, indicating Badub's music is integrated into the current build.
badub.quote: Dude, this song is such a banger.

zeina.summary: Progress on a specific level entity was blocked because the required animations, created by Zeina, were not yet complete, highlighting a key team dependency.
zeina.quote: Unfortunately Zeina's gone today. Otherwise, she maybe would have finished the animation for the guy here which would have been very cool.

key_stories.title: The Infinite Ocean on a Finite Console
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create a convincing, vast ocean background but was constrained by N64 hardware limitations. After failed attempts with standard techniques, he developed a novel solution using a camera-relative 3D plane, refined with feedback from Biobak, to successfully create an illusion of infinite distance.
key_stories.challenge: To create a background that looks like a vast, endless ocean on N64 hardware, which aggressively culls distant geometry and makes large environments look fake or broken.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted a standard far-away 3D model, which was culled by the hardware. He then tried a non-fogged background plane (NFBG), but found it looked unconvincing when level elements touched the horizon. This led to the final, novel idea of a camera-relative 3D plane that fakes perspective and parallax.
key_stories.outcome: A hybrid solution was developed where a 3D model of the water is curved up at the edges and dynamically moves with the camera. This, combined with color gradients suggested by Biobak, creates a convincing illusion of an infinite ocean within the console's hardware limits.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the NBG is just not the possible here, of course culling is possible in the N64 but culling is not even what we're thinking about we are right now thinking about how to make the background look good.

key_stories.title: The Collaborative Switch Upgrade
key_stories.summary: While Kaze was struggling with the dated look of the original Mario 64 P-switch, team member Biobak provided a brand-new, custom model. The immediate collaboration resulted in a significant visual upgrade for a key level asset.
key_stories.challenge: The original P-switch model from Super Mario 64 had visual flaws and looked dated compared to the new level's assets.
key_stories.process: While Kaze was attempting to fix the shading on the stock P-switch model, Biobak sent him a completely new, custom-made model during the stream. Kaze immediately imported it, praised its efficiency and visual appeal, and replaced the old asset on the spot.
key_stories.outcome: The level's visual quality was improved by replacing the placeholder asset with a high-quality, custom model that respects the original's design while looking significantly better.
key_stories.key_quote: This is so much better than the one we had before. This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one. Very, very nice.

key_stories.title: The Accidental Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Concerned about performance, Kaze discovered he was accidentally using an unoptimized export format for his 3D models. Correcting this single setting instantly doubled the level's performance, turning a potential optimization nightmare into a surprising and validating win.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring a large, graphically intense level could run at an acceptable framerate on original N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze was testing the level on N64 hardware and noted performance was acceptable but not ideal. Upon investigation, he realized he had been using an inefficient model export format for an extended period. Simply changing the setting to the correct one (F3DX2) immediately and dramatically improved performance.
key_stories.outcome: By discovering and correcting the export setting, Kaze found a massive, 'free' performance boost. This accident provided confidence that the level's design was viable and could be further optimized to run smoothly.
key_stories.key_quote: I found out when we were in 64 testing this level... I was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DX2. So we had twice the verdict loads, twice the triangle comments... and it still ran fine.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned being approached by a merchandise company and brainstormed ideas for legally selling items like game boxes and OST ROMs.
questions: How serious are the plans to create and sell physical merchandise?
What is the line between celebrating a game and infringing on IP, and how do you plan to navigate that with commercial products?
Is this a potential path to making game development a full-time, self-sustaining career?

open_questions.context: Kaze noted that his partner, Zeina, handles animation, and her unavailability meant a certain character couldn't be implemented yet.
questions: How do you two manage the dynamic of being both life partners and key collaborators on a demanding creative project?
Can you walk me through the typical workflow between your programming of a character and her animating it?
What are the unique advantages or challenges that come from this close professional and personal relationship?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned fixing a critical bug that had been causing stability issues on N64 hardware, a problem that also affected his previous project, OnlyUp64.
questions: You mentioned fixing a major stability bug. Can you describe what the technical problem was?
What was the process of hunting down that bug like?
What did it feel like to finally solve a problem that plagued not just one, but two of your major projects?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated he has a full-time job as a programmer and works on this project on the side.
questions: How do you balance the creative energy required for this project with the demands of a full-time technical job?
Does your day job ever influence your work on the hack, or vice-versa, in terms of skills or ideas?
What does a typical 'day in the life' look like, juggling both responsibilities?
